go in action

å‘ç°å¯ä»¥åœ¨https://livebook.manning.com/book/go-in-action/çœ‹è¿™æœ¬ä¹¦ï¼Œæ‰“ç®—è¯»è¯»çœ‹ã€‚

respective å„è‡ªçš„

retrieve å–å›ã€æ£€ç´¢ã€æŒ½å›ã€æŒ½æ•‘

dynamic åŠ¨æ€çš„

mechanism æœºåˆ¶ã€é€”å¾„ã€æœºæ¢°è£…ç½®

corruption å‡ºé”™ã€å •è½

populate å±…ä½äº

anonymous åŒ¿åçš„

closure å…³é—­[U]ã€ç›–å­[C]ã€é—­åŒ…

tricky ç‹¡çŒ¾çš„ã€å›°éš¾çš„ã€å¤æ‚çš„

mechanic ç»“æ„ã€æŠ€æœ¯

  • å˜é‡å£°æ˜

Here you see the use of the short variable declaration operator (:=). This operator is used to both declare and initialize variables at the same time. The type of each value being returned is used by the compiler to determine the type for each variable, respectively. The short variable declaration operator is just a shortcut to streamline your code and make the code more readable. The variable it declares is no different than any other variable you may declare when using the keyword var.

è¿™é‡Œè¯´:=åªæ˜¯ä¸ªshortcutï¼Œå’Œvarå£°æ˜å‡ºæ¥çš„æ²¡æœ‰åŒºåˆ«ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯:=ä¸èƒ½åœ¨å‡½æ•°å¤–éƒ¨å®šä¹‰å˜é‡ï¼Œåªèƒ½å®šä¹‰å±€éƒ¨å˜é‡ï¼Œè€Œvarå¯ä»¥å®šä¹‰å…¨å±€å˜é‡ã€‚

A good rule of thumb when declaring variables is to use the keyword var when declaring variables that will be initialized to their zero value, and to use the short variable declaration operator when youâ€™re providing extra initialization or making a function call.

åˆå§‹åŒ–å˜é‡ç”¨varè¿˜æ˜¯:=å‘¢ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œå»ºè®®ç›´æ¥å®šä¹‰ä¸ºé›¶å€¼çš„æ—¶å€™ç”¨varï¼Œä¸ç„¶ç”¨:=

  • å¼•ç”¨ç±»å‹

Channels are also a reference type in Go like maps and slices

  • åŒæ­¥

A WaitGroup is a great way to track when a goroutine is finished performing its work. A WaitGroup is a counting semaphore, and weâ€™ll use it to count off goroutines as they finish their work.

Thereâ€™s something else interesting about the method call to Done: the WaitGroup value was never passed into the anonymous function as a parameter, yet the anonymous function has access to it.

  • For range

The keyword range can be used with arrays, strings, slices, maps, and channels. When we use for range to iterate over a slice, we get two values back on each iteration. The first is the index position of the element weâ€™re iterating over, and the second is a copy of the value in that element

  • pointer variable

Pointer variables are great for sharing variables between functions. They allow functions to access and change the state of a variable that was declared within the scope of a different function and possibly a different goroutine.

In Go, all variables are passed by value. Since the value of a pointer variable is the address to the memory being pointed to, passing pointer variables between functions is still considered a pass by value.

  • é—­åŒ…ä¸åŒ¿åå‡½æ•°

https://segmentfault.com/a/1190000018689134

tbc.

entry.title: Hello World
entry.content:
Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub.
